ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned a lot about various fields through reading recent papers and discussing them with faculty and students. We presented an experiment and wrote a detailed abstract which helped with our experiment development skills.
I learned how to critically evaluate research articles from outside fields.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Only having to read two papers a week makes the class manageable and allows you to put more effort into reading the papers well. Weaknesses: Student and faculty discussion skills are varying which makes it hard to have full discussions without the question:answer formula often used by teachers.

A strength was the student only discussion session before we had the faculty discussion. I thought the faculty discussions were best when we didn't go around in a circle to describe figures, but actually talked about and discussed the paper.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes because it connects interdisciplinary fields well and exposes students to new methods not typically covered in department specific discussions.
Yes, I think this course was both interesting and beneficial in terms of critical thinking skills. It was also a good way to be exposed to research out of your own field.
